Description: Small mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; poorly modelled and rather eroded back, with basic features indicated; elytra and prothorax shown by single line; side view unknown; underside deeply incised with three hieroglyphic signs consisting of falcon, Maat feather and sun-disc; pierced lengthwise; quite worn surfaces.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This small scarab belongs to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). It was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, notably on Punic sites and in the Levant (Gorton 1996, 112-114, type XXXI). Most signs are legible, but reading is difficult: the hieroglyphs are possibly only used here for their intrinsic magical value, as often for this type of scarab (Gorton 1996, 93). Similar inscribed scarab with no real sense to the inscription: BM 1886,0401.1670, Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 88.870 and Paris, Louvre Museum E8056 bis.12. Gorton included this scarab in her large group XXVIII A (Gorton 1996, 98, A144a), though this type concerns normally only glazed composition scarabs and not Egyptian blue ones. Another Egyptian blue scarab, BM 1886,0401.1638, was assigned to that group (Gorton 1996, 98, A142). Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 88.868 would fit better her group XXX A: the motifs are similar to the ones found for her group XXVIII A, but they are roughly carved in coloured pastes and especially Egyptian blue (Gorton 1996, 109-111). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 98, Type XXVIII A144a) (but wrong group)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.33) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5774 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
